title: Transmission Electron Microscopy Exploration of Solution-Grown Lead Oxide Nanosheets: Unveiling Crystallinity and Defects
content: Pb(II) oxide (PbO) exists in two forms: (red) litharge, also known as α-PbO and (yellow) massicot, β-PbO. Both compounds have a very simple structure, with litharge having a tetragonal cell (P4/nmm) and massicot having an orthorhombic cell (Pbma). α – β transformation usually occurs at around 490 oC. However, β-PbO can also exist at room temperature [1]. Depending on the synthesis parameters, a larger yield of either litharge or massicot can be obtained using specific wet chemical routes. Many reports have mentioned an incommensurate phase transition of the litharge at low temperatures (≈ 208 K) [2]. A wide variety of chemical oscillations exist between the litharge and massicot with possible chaotic states [3]. In this study, we have synthesised PbO using a wet chemical route, which yielded mixed α and β phases. A detailed TEM study has been done to understand these nanosheets' structure and crystallographic features.
